Description: Body sherd of Corinthian black-figured red-ground pottery column-krater; interior glazed black with single band in added red. Exterior: at top, maeander band above band of double staggered dots between lines; below, black-figure processional scene to left; from left, much of male figure (red on face and neck) carrying an oinochoe in added white in his left hand and uncertain white object, perhaps a cushion or bag, on his back; most of white-painted male figure, looking back to right, carrying a red oinochoe in his left hand and a tripod on his right shoulder; only right arm, torso and part of left arm remaining of third male figure, carrying a white tripod in his left hand and possibly a white dinos on his right shoulder.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Payne identified the sherd as coming from a column krater. Venit suggests that the image on the vase is similar to processional scenes painted in Egyptian tombs.
The piece has the same unusual decorative scheme as Alexandria 9507, which may be from the other side of the same vase.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 63, no. 224, pl. 51, no. 224)
Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (p. 329, no. 1470)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.331) (phase 3)
